title: 109_hr1595
content: The Guam World War II Loyalty Recognition Act recognizes the suffering and loyalty of Guam residents during World War II. It includes provisions for payments for Guam World War II claims, adjudication, and a grants program to memorialize the occupation of Guam. The United States recognizes the suffering and loyalty of Guam residents during World War II, acknowledging the harm they endured under Japanese occupation and their unwavering loyalty to the United States despite facing great danger. SEC. 3. PAYMENTS FOR GUAM WORLD WAR II CLAIMS. Payments for Death, Personal Injury, Forced Labor, Forced March, and Internment are made by the Secretary of the Treasury according to certification under section 4(b)(8). $25,000 is paid to eligible survivors of compensable Guam decedents, and $15,000 is paid to compensable Guam victims who have suffered specified injuries. Payments under this section are made by the Secretary of the Treasury for compensable Guam victims. The amount varies based on the type of injury, with $12,000 for certain injuries, $10,000 for others, and $7,000 for deceased victims. Survivor payments are distributed according to specified guidelines. These payments are treated as authorized awards under the law. If the deceased victim has a living spouse, the full payment goes to the spouse. If there is a spouse and children, half goes to the spouse and the other half to the child(ren). If there is no spouse but children, the payment goes to the child(ren). If there are no spouse, children, but living parent(s), the payment goes to the parent(s). The term "compensable Guam decedent" refers to an individual who was a resident of Guam and died during World War II due to the attack and occupation by Japanese forces or during the liberation by US forces. The term "compensable Guam victim" refers to an individual meeting the same criteria. The term "victim" refers to an individual who suffered severe personal injuries or forced labor during the attack and occupation of Guam by Japanese forces in World War II or during the liberation by US forces. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission will define what constitutes severe personal injuries or personal injuries for compensation purposes. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission will define severe personal injury or personal injury for compensation purposes. SEC. 4. ADJUDICATION. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission has the authority to adjudicate claims and determine eligibility for payments under section 3. The chairman is responsible for creating necessary rules and regulations, which must be published in the Federal Register. Claims must be submitted in the required manner and form for the Commission to determine eligibility for payments. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission specifies the manner and form for submitting claims. Claims must be filed within one year of public notice in the Federal Register. Decisions on claims are made by majority vote, in writing, stating reasons for approval or denial, and specifying payment amount and distribution. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission deducts previous payments under the Guam Meritorious Claims Act of 1945, does not pay interest on awarded payments, and prohibits remuneration exceeding one percent for representational services. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission imposes fines or imprisonment for exceeding remuneration limits, appeals go to the Commission with final decisions, certifications for payment are sent to the Treasury, and affidavits are treated according to section 3. The Foreign Claims Settlement Commission treats a claim accompanied by an affidavit as establishing prima facie eligibility for payment without further documentation, except as required. Material facts must include a detailed description of the injury or circumstance supporting the claim and the level of payment sought. Acceptance of payment for a claim related to a compensable Guam decedent or victim releases related claims. The acceptance of payment for a claim related to a compensable Guam decedent or victim releases all related claims under the Guam Meritorious Claims Act of 1945, the implementing regulations, or this Act. Penalties for false claims apply to submissions under this subsection. SEC. 5. Grants program to memorialize the occupation of Guam during World War II. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a grants program to award grants for research, educational, and media activities memorializing the events of the occupation of Guam during World War II. Eligibility for grants requires submitting an application with specified information. $5,000,000 is authorized for appropriations for this program. The Secretary of the Interior authorized $5,000,000 for a grant program to memorialize the events of the occupation of Guam during World War II. The funds are available until September 30, 2011, and unobligated funds can also be used for this purpose.
